summary: This document contains instructions to a focus group regarding the indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell. It summarizes the three criminal counts against her: conspiracy to transport minors (1994-2004), conspiracy to commit sex trafficking (2001-2004), and sex trafficking of a specific minor victim (2001-2004). The instructions explain the legal elements and burden of proof for each count.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with three counts related to conspiring to transport minors and sex trafficking of minors between 1994 and 2004.

events.title: Conspiracy to Transport Minors Period
events.description: Time period during which Ghislaine Maxwell is alleged to have conspired to transport minors with intent for sexual activity.

events.title: Conspiracy to Commit Sex Trafficking Period
events.description: Time period for the alleged conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Sex Trafficking of Minor Victim-4
events.description: Time period for the specific sex trafficking charge related to Minor Victim-4.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell is charged with three counts: conspiracy to transport minors (1994-2004), conspiracy to commit sex trafficking (2001-2004), and sex trafficking of Minor Victim-4 (2001-2004).

The document explains that the government's burden of proof for the focus group exercise is 'preponderance of the evidence' (more likely than not), not 'beyond a reasonable doubt' as in a criminal trial.
Count One involves transporting minors with intent for sexual activity under New York law, where a person under 17 cannot consent.
Count Two and Three involve sex trafficking, defined as recruiting/transporting a person under 18 knowing they would engage in a commercial sex act.
The document mentions that Maxwell could be found guilty under an 'aiding and abetting' theory for Count Three if she assisted others in committing the crime.
